in Nov 2005. It is officially known by the acronym NPT.

Naypyidaw is rather unique in this entire region. It's a fully developed large city, but with very few inhabitants for its size, so you can experience the rather unprecedented Asian experience of never having to be stuck in traffic. Whether this weird situation will remain when Burma's economy begins to boom is another matter since the lack of gridlock is certainly not down to superb road planning and cutting edge traffic control despite the wide boulevards and Parisian-sized roundabouts.

Naypyidaw was a rather secretive construction project by the brutal, ruling military junta in the early 2000s and, in Nov 2005, was suddenly officially announced as Myanmar's new capital. Government workers were given two months notice that they would have to move from

with the re-location of all government offices and ministries. Most embassies and international organisations, like the UN, have not relocated since an education and health infrastructure is not yet in place.

A newly built toll motorway connects Yangon to NPT. It's 320 km (200 mi) long with a service area containing a fuel station and an outrageously expensive, grubby and tasteless restaurant just past the halfway point if you're coming from Yangon.
, a train leaves at 12:00 and arrives in Naypyidaw at 21:00 (9 hr).

To handle increased traffic to the capital, the existing airport at Ela was upgraded to handle larger planes. It lies 16 km (10 mi) southeast of Kyatpyae. This airport is now listed as a destination for all domestic airlines: Myanma Airways, Yangon Airways, Air Mandalay and Air Bagan.

In reality, only the army generals and a few foreign visitors fly to Naypyidaw while most others travel by bus.
From Yangon a bus travels along the new 8-lane toll highway for about 4 hr from Yangon to the capital, which unusually just springs out of nowhere at a nondescript intersection.
This is typical transportation in Naypyidaw.
Similar to those in Bangkok although called a "thaw lar gyi" in Myanmar.

value: content=Three enormous sculptures depicting the three most important kings in Burmese history: Anawrahta, Bayinnaung and Alaungpaya U Aung Zeya.
content=Exhibits of plants having medicinal applications from all of the major regions of Burma. There are thousands of plants at the park, representing hundreds of different species.

content=Opened in 2008 with some 420 animals and a climate-controlled penguin house. It is the largest zoo in Burma as most of the animals were relocated from the zoo in Rangoon at the same time as the government officials were making the same journey. When a well known comedian consequently announced that "all our animals are going to Naypiydaw", he was predictably imprisoned.

content=A prominent landmark in Naypyidaw. The pagoda, which houses a Buddha tooth relic from China, is a replica of Shwedagon Pagoda in Yangon and stands 100 m high. It also has a Maha Hsutaungpyae Buddha image in the Maha Pasadabhumi Gandhakuti Chamber, four jade Buddha images in the pagoda's hollow cave; a 33 m high flagpole; Bo tree garden with Maha Bo Tree and the images of the 28 Buddhas, Marlini Mangala Lake with the chamber of Shin Uppagutta, and a pagoda museum.
content=Park with a playground and water fountain complex, which hosts a musical light show every night.
content=Naypyidaw has two golf courses, Nay Pyi Taw City Golf Course and Yaypyar Golf Course.
content=A small water park along Ngalaik Dam, near Kyweshin Village on Ngalaik Lake. Has water slides, resorts, lodgings and a beach.

Naypyitaw Myoma Market is the commercial centre of Naypyidaw. Other shopping areas include Thapye Chaung Market and Junction Centre Naypyidaw. In the "hotel zone" are two medium-sized shopping malls: Junction and Capital, each of which have a supermarket and restaurants. Junction also has a cinema.

The hotel zone has a handful of villa-style hotels that dot the hills on the outskirts of the city. There are currently twelve hotels in or near Naypyidaw. Eight of these are within the Naypyidaw Hotel Zone.
